study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Iranian green tea mouthwash containing 1% tannin versus chlorhexidine mouthwash on dental plaque and chronic gingivitis.
results_summary: Both mouthwashes showed significant improvements in gingival, plaque, and bleeding indices within their respective groups, but no significant differences between the groups. The green tea mouthwash caused significantly less tooth staining than chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: 40 volunteer dental students with a gingival index ≥1.
effective_dosage: 15 mL, twice a day for 1 minute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether erythropoietin (EPO) mouthwash could reduce the incidence and severity of oral mucositis (OM) in patients undergoing autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that EPO mouthwash significantly reduced the incidence of OM (27.5% vs. 77.5%), lowered its severity, shortened its duration (1.92 vs. 5.42 days), and reduced the duration of neutropenic fever compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Hodgkin disease, or multiple myeloma undergoing autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
effective_dosage: 50 IU/ml, 15 ml four times a day.
study_duration: From the start of high-dose chemotherapy until day +14 post-transplantation or hospital discharge, whichever occurred first.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tranexamic acid (TA) mouthwash inhibits lysine decarboxylase (LDC) activity, biofilm accumulation, and gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) exudation in a human gingivitis model.
results_summary: TA inhibited biofilm LDC and reduced plaque index (PI) by altering the correlation between PI and biofilm lysine content. However, TA's retention in saliva partially relieved GCF suppression without restoring biofilm lysine levels, and it may impair dental epithelial attachments by inhibiting lysine transporter uptake.
population_specificity: Young adults
effective_dosage: 5% or 10% TA mouthwash, three times daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial properties of propolis-containing mouthrinse compared to chlorhexidine and control solutions in an in vitro multispecies biofilm model.
results_summary: The propolis-containing mouthrinse showed no significant reduction in colony-forming units (CFU), while chlorhexidine mouthrinse demonstrated strong CFU reduction. All tested toothpastes, including those with propolis, showed significant CFU reduction compared to the saline control.
population_specificity: In vitro multispecies biofilm model (six-species biofilms grown anaerobically on hydroxyapatite disks).
effective_dosage: Not specified for mouthrinse (0.12% chlorhexidine was used as a comparator).
study_duration: Biofilms were exposed to treatments during 45-minute intervals over 64.5 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity of an extemporaneously prepared herbal mouthwash and compare its potential as an alternative to chemical-based mouthwashes like Chlorhexidine gluconate (CHX).
results_summary: The herbal mouthwash demonstrated effective antimicrobial activity against various bacterial strains and may offer an alternative to chemical mouthwashes with better patient compliance and enhanced antimicrobial properties. The study also reviewed existing patents, highlighting the growing market trend for herbal mouthwashes.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the substantivity of a single 0.2% Chlorhexidine mouthwash in saliva after neutralization with tooth-brushing and 1% acetic acid, focusing on its effect on bacterial regrowth.
results_summary: The study found that a single 0.2% Chlorhexidine mouthwash significantly reduced bacterial vitality for up to 7 hours, but this effect was shortened to 3 hours when followed by tooth-brushing and acetic acid. The substantivity of Chlorhexidine extended its antibacterial effect by at least double the duration compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 15 healthy individuals
study_duration: Saliva samples collected up to 7 hours post-treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwashes (one with 0.1% hyaluronic acid and one without) on post-surgical adverse events, antiplaque, antigingivitis, and antistaining outcomes in dental implant patients.
results_summary: The CHX⊗HYL mouthwash showed significantly lower post-surgical edema (20% vs. 78%) compared to CHX alone, but no differences in plaque, gingivitis, or staining indexes were found between groups. Intragroup analysis revealed significant improvements in plaque and gingival indexes only for CHX⊗HYL, while staining increased significantly for both mouthwashes.
population_specificity: 40 patients undergoing dental implant treatment.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash (with or without 0.1% hyaluronic acid), used for 15 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an octenidine-based mouthwash as an adjunct to periodontal therapy in HIV-positive patients with periodontal disease.
results_summary: The OCT-based mouthwash showed a more pronounced decrease in periodontal indices (PBI and PD) at 1-month follow-up and eliminated atypical microorganisms, but these benefits were not sustained at 3 months.
population_specificity: HIV-positive patients with clinically diagnosed periodontal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of caffeine mouth rinsing on 3-km cycling performance and its interaction with the CYP1A2 polymorphism.
results_summary: Caffeine mouth rinsing combined with ingestion improved performance in both AA homozygotes (3.4%) and AC heterozygotes (4.1%), with AC heterozygotes also benefiting from ingestion alone (6.0%). Performance gains were more pronounced in subjects who exercised before 10:00 h compared to later.
population_specificity: 38 recreational cyclists genotyped for the CYP1A2 rs762551 polymorphism (AA homozygotes or AC heterozygotes).
effective_dosage: 25 mL of 1.14% caffeine solution rinsed before each trial; 6 mg/kg BW caffeine ingested 1 h prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash with a sodium lauryl sulphate (SLS) dentifrice affects its plaque-inhibiting and gingivitis-reducing efficacy.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that using an SLS dentifrice as a slurry rinse significantly reduced the plaque-inhibiting effect of CHX mouthwash, but no significant difference was observed when SLS dentifrice was applied as a paste. The combined use of CHX mouthwash and SLS dentifrice was not contraindicated, regardless of the order of use.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years with good general health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether prophylactic use of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash reduces post-extraction bacteraemia (PEB) and compare different CHX application methods.
results_summary: A 0.2% CHX mouthwash significantly reduced PEB duration at 15 minutes (4% vs. 23% in controls). Subgingival irrigation did not enhance efficacy, while supragingival irrigation reduced it. Streptococci were the most common bacteria identified.
population_specificity: 201 patients undergoing tooth extraction.
effective_dosage: 0.2% CHX mouthwash; 1% CHX for subgingival/supragingival irrigation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of topical treatments, including tetracycline antibiotic mouthwash, for recurrent idiopathic aphthous ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that tetracycline antibiotic mouthwash was among the interventions reviewed for treating recurrent aphthous ulcers, but specific efficacy details were not highlighted in the abstract. The GRADE evaluation suggested varying levels of evidence quality for the included interventions.
population_specificity: People with recurrent idiopathic aphthous ulcers, including those with lesions larger than 10 mm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial substantivity and clinical efficacy of different commercial CPC mouthrinses using in vitro and in vivo methods.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in antibacterial efficacy among the mouthrinses, with Crest Pro Health (CPH) showing the highest efficacy, followed by Colgate Total US (CT750), Scope Mouthwash (SCP), and Colgate Total Puerto Rico (CT450). The in vitro disk retention assay correlated with clinical performance, indicating CPC bioavailability influences antimicrobial effectiveness.
population_specificity: Qualified adult panelists in a controlled, double-blind, randomized, crossover design.
effective_dosage: 450 ppm (SCP, CT450), 700 ppm (CPH), 750 ppm (CT750) formulated CPC.
study_duration: Not specified (treatment days with plaque sampling at 15 and 45 minutes post-rinsing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mouthwash, dentifrice, or tongue cleaning as adjuncts to toothbrushing on reducing intra-oral malodour and tongue coating compared to toothbrushing alone.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwashes containing active ingredients like chlorhexidine + cetylpyridinium chloride + zinc or zinc chloride + cetylpyridinium chloride significantly reduced oral malodour when used adjunctively to toothbrushing, though the overall evidence was limited and the recommendation strength was graded as 'weak'.
population_specificity: Systemically healthy patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Achillea millefolium distillate solution in treating chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis compared to a routine solution.
results_summary: The study found that Achillea millefolium distillate significantly reduced the severity of oral mucositis over 14 days, while the control group using the routine solution experienced worsening symptoms. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 56 cancer patients with chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: 15 mL of a mixture of routine solution and distilled A. millefolium, gargled 4 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pilocarpine mouthwash in relieving dry mouth symptoms compared to a water rinse control.
results_summary: Pilocarpine mouthwash significantly reduced dry mouth symptoms (VAS scores) and increased stimulated salivary flow rate, with 47% of patients showing overall improvement. Side effects were minor and limited to oral discomfort in a small subset of patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with xerostomia (40 participants, divided into pilocarpine and control groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of different oral hygiene procedures, including mouthwash, on reducing volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs) in subjects with oral malodor.
results_summary: Tooth brushing alone did not significantly reduce oral malodor, but adding mouthwash or tongue cleaning significantly reduced VSCs. The greatest reduction occurred when all three procedures (tooth brushing, mouthwash, and tongue cleaning) were combined.
population_specificity: Thirty male volunteers with oral malodor.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mouthwash with chlorine dioxide used, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of a 2% green tea mouthwash compared to a placebo for controlling plaque and gingivitis.
results_summary: The green tea mouthwash significantly reduced plaque and gingivitis scores compared to the placebo, with statistically significant improvements in both plaque index (PI) and gingival index (GI) after 28 days.
population_specificity: 110 male subjects aged 18-60 with at least 20 sound natural teeth, a PI ≥1.5, and a GI ≥1.0.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of chlorhexidine and Persica mouthwashes, along with electric toothbrushes, in improving gingival enlargement in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: Persica mouthwash showed similar efficacy to chlorhexidine in improving gingival conditions, but neither treatment reduced gingival enlargement to clinically acceptable levels. No significant differences were found between the mouthwash groups or between manual and electric toothbrush groups.
population_specificity: 72 orthodontic patients with at least two sites of gingival enlargement.
effective_dosage: According to respective manufacturer's instructions (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral antiseptics (mouthwashes) in reducing cariogenic plaque in patients with fixed orthodontic appliances.
results_summary: The study found evidence supporting the effectiveness of oral mouthwashes in controlling cariogenic plaque in orthodontic patients, with 11 of 15 included studies classified as high methodological quality. Different mouthwash formulations (e.g., chlorhexidine, Cetylpyridinium, sanguinaria, NaF, AmF/SnF2, Listerine) showed positive results.
population_specificity: Patients with fixed orthodontic appliances.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of Aloe vera mouthwash with benzydamine mouthwash in alleviating radiation-induced mucositis in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: Aloe vera mouthwash was as effective as benzydamine mouthwash in reducing mucositis severity, with no significant difference in onset or maximum severity. No side effects were reported for Aloe vera mouthwash.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients receiving conventional radiation therapy.
study_duration: Duration of radiation therapy (specific length not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the plaque index in orthodontic patients based on various factors, including the use of mouthwash.
results_summary: The study found that plaque accumulation was significantly influenced by brushing practices and type of ligatures, but the abstract does not specify the impact of mouthwash on plaque index.
population_specificity: 131 patients (37% male, 63% female) undergoing multi-bracket fixed orthodontic treatment.
study_duration: Study conducted from September to November 2011 (duration of intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of nystatin and Biotène(®) mouthwash Oral Rinse in controlling Candida growth in total laryngectomy patients with tracheoesophageal voice prostheses.
results_summary: Both nystatin and Biotène(®) mouthwash reduced Candida counts compared to no medication, though only nystatin showed a statistically significant improvement. Biotène(®) mouthwash had higher adherence rates and was less costly, making it a preferable alternative despite similar efficacy.
population_specificity: Total laryngectomy patients with tracheoesophageal voice prostheses (21 participants, 15 analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of toluidine blue-mediated photodynamic therapy (TB-PDT) with a dexamethasone mouthwash in treating erosive-atrophic oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The study found that both TB-PDT and dexamethasone mouthwash significantly reduced lesion intensity and pain, with the mouthwash showing greater improvement in pain relief. However, there was no significant difference in overall treatment efficacy between the two groups.
population_specificity: 25 patients with keratotic-atrophic-erosive oral lichen planus.
effective_dosage: Mouthwash diluted with dexamethasone (0.5 mg tablet in 5 ml water) used for 5 minutes, followed by nystatin rinse (30 drops of 100,000 units) for 5 minutes.
study_duration: Treatment was administered during two visits, with follow-up at 1 month.

study_goal: To determine if MuGard mouthwash is effective in reducing pain and ulceration in patients with biopsy-proven erosive oral lichen planus when painful lesions are already present.
results_summary: MuGard significantly reduced pain and ulceration in patients with oral lichen planus, with notable reductions in pain scores and ulceration severity. The number-needed-to-treat for >50% pain reduction was 1.25, and for complete relief, it was 2.5.
population_specificity: Patients with biopsy-proven erosive oral lichen planus.
effective_dosage: One teaspoonful swished for 1 minute, 5 times a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosage of Chamomilla recutita extract in mouthwash for reducing the incidence and severity of oral mucositis in adult patients undergoing allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
results_summary: The study found that a 1% dosage of C recutita extract in mouthwash significantly reduced the incidence, intensity, and duration of oral mucositis compared to standard care alone, with no moderate or severe adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing allogenic HSCT.
effective_dosage: 0.5%, 1%, and 2% liquid extract of C recutita in mouthwash.
study_duration: Daily evaluation during the intervention period (exact duration not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a mouthwash containing lysine (0.4%) and glycerol monolaurate (0.2%) could eliminate oral H. pylori and its impact on gastric H. pylori eradication.
results_summary: The mouthwash solution achieved a 72.58% effectiveness rate in eliminating oral H. pylori, significantly higher than traditional gastric eradication treatments (10.67%). Treating oral H. pylori infection increased gastric eradication success from 61.33% to 82.26%.
population_specificity: 159 symptomatic individuals with stomach pain and 118 asymptomatic individuals without stomach complaints.
effective_dosage: Lysine (0.4%) and glycerol monolaurate (0.2%) in mouthwash solution (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if using 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash before dental prophylaxis reduces air contamination from aerosolized sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: The study found that prior use of 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash significantly reduced microbial contamination (CFU) in all tested positions compared to distilled water, with statistical significance (P < 0.001).
population_specificity: 23 patients aged 10-40 years undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash used for one minute.
study_duration: Two phases (T1 and T2) with a 30-day interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mouthwash with chlorhexidine was effective in reducing contamination risk during transgastric NOTES procedures.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwash with chlorhexidine was effective in reducing contamination, but noted a higher bacterial load in patients using proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing transgastric NOTES procedures, particularly those using PPIs.
interactions: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) were noted to increase bacterial load in the stomach.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Pistacia atlantica Var. mutica extract mouthwash versus chlorhexidine (CHX) in reducing dental plaque bacteria and subgingival microorganisms.
results_summary: The study found that both P. atlantica and CHX mouthwashes significantly reduced aerobic plaque bacterial counts compared to placebo, with CHX showing a stronger effect. P. atlantica was deemed effective and potentially a better alternative due to fewer side effects.
population_specificity: 28 patients with dental plaque.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash reduces the risk of bacteraemia following routine intra-alveolar tooth extraction.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in bacteraemia incidence in the chlorhexidine group (27.1%) compared to the control group (52.4%). Bacteraemia was most frequently detected at 1 minute post-extraction, with persistence in 26.7% of cases after 15 minutes.
population_specificity: 101 subjects undergoing intra-alveolar dental extractions under local anaesthesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of green tea mouthwash versus chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash in managing pain and trismus in patients with acute pericoronitis.
results_summary: Green tea mouthwash significantly reduced pain and analgesic use compared to CHX, though differences in trismus reduction were not statistically significant. Both mouthwashes showed similar effectiveness in improving maximum mouth opening by day 7.
population_specificity: 97 patients with acute pericoronitis.
effective_dosage: 5% green tea mouthwash (study group) or 0.12% CHX mouth rinse (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between dental anxiety, exaggerated gag reflex, and oral hygiene parameters, suggesting supplementary aids like fluoride mouthwash for maintaining oral hygiene in affected patients.
results_summary: The study found higher plaque index (PI) and Decayed, Missing, and Filled Teeth (DMFT) scores in patients with dental anxiety and exaggerated gag reflex compared to controls, recommending fluoride mouthwash as a supplementary aid to improve oral hygiene without triggering gag reflexes.
population_specificity: Patients with dental anxiety (n=68), exaggerated gag reflex (n=54), and a control group of 200 individuals undergoing dental treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether royal jelly, when added to standard mouthwash therapy (benzydamine hydrochloride and nystatin rinses), could improve oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that royal jelly significantly shortened the resolution time of oral mucositis compared to the control group, demonstrating improved healing and symptom relief.
population_specificity: 103 patients undergoing radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether topical sucralfate and clindamycin mouthwash could reduce postoperative pain in children after tonsillectomy.
results_summary: The study found that both sucralfate and clindamycin mouthwash significantly reduced throat pain compared to placebo in the first four days post-surgery, with fewer adverse effects like bleeding and food intolerance in the treatment groups. Pain scores and acetaminophen use were lower in the treatment groups, though no significant differences were observed by day 5.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 12 years undergoing tonsillectomy for sleep apnea, snoring, or chronic infections.
effective_dosage: 10 mL of mouthwash solution used for 1 minute, 3 times daily for 3 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Aloe vera mouthwash against chlorhexidine and placebo in reducing dental plaque over a 4-day period.
results_summary: Aloe vera mouthwash was equally effective as chlorhexidine in reducing plaque, with no statistically significant difference between the two, and both were significantly better than placebo. No side effects were reported for Aloe vera mouthwash.
population_specificity: 300 systemically healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, safety, antiplaque, and antigingivitis properties of a herbal mouthwash with chlorhexidine mouthwash and normal saline.
results_summary: The study found that both herbal and chlorhexidine mouthwashes were equally effective in reducing plaque and gingivitis, with no significant difference between them. Chlorhexidine was superior to saline, but it had more side effects, while the herbal mouthwash only caused mild burning sensation.
population_specificity: 72 undergraduate students aged 18-24 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various oral care interventions, including mouthwash, in preventing and treating oral mucositis in cancer patients undergoing radio- or chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine mouthwash was not effective for preventing oral mucositis in adults with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy. No guidelines could be established for mixed medication mouthwash due to inadequate or conflicting evidence.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of an alcohol-free essential oil mouthwash (AF-EOMW) in reducing plaque accumulation and oral pathogen levels among institutionalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in plaque index, denture cleanliness, or salivary pathogen levels between the AF-EOMW group and the tap water control group at any time point. The researchers concluded that AF-EOMW was not superior to tap water for improving oral hygiene in this population.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly individuals with significant loss of autonomy.
effective_dosage: Twice daily rinsing (specific volume not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and incidence of bleeding after dentoalveolar operations in patients using anticoagulants, specifically assessing the role of tranexamic acid mouthwash in postoperative care.
results_summary: The study found that tranexamic acid mouthwash was effective in controlling postoperative bleeding in patients taking vitamin K antagonists, with no severe bleeds reported. Mild bleeding occurred in 7% of anticoagulant users, but all cases were self-managed with gauze compression.
population_specificity: 206 patients undergoing dentoalveolar operations, including 103 on anticoagulants (71 on thrombocyte aggregation inhibitors, 32 on vitamin K antagonists) and 103 not on anticoagulants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cariostatic efficacy and acceptability of aqueous and ethanolic liquorice extracts as mouthwash compared to chlorhexidine gluconate in pediatric patients.
results_summary: Both liquorice extracts significantly reduced mutans streptococci colony counts and increased salivary pH immediately after rinsing, with the ethanolic extract showing superior efficacy compared to the control. The antimicrobial effect was immediate but had limited retentivity.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 7-14 years (N = 60).
effective_dosage: 15% aqueous liquorice mouthwash, 3.75% ethanolic liquorice mouthwash, and 0.156% chlorhexidine gluconate (control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of green tea mouthwash in controlling postoperative pain following surgical removal of impacted third molars.
results_summary: The study found that green tea mouthwash significantly reduced postoperative pain (measured by VAS) on days 3-7 compared to placebo and decreased the number of analgesics used, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: 43 patients (mean age 24 years) undergoing bilateral removal of impacted third molars.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used from first to seventh postoperative day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of posaconazole prophylaxis versus polyene mouthwash prophylaxis in preventing invasive fungal diseases in high-risk AML patients.
results_summary: The study found that posaconazole prophylaxis was cost-effective compared to polyene mouthwash, primarily due to shorter ICU stays and reduced overall hospitalization costs. However, antifungal treatment costs were slightly higher in the posaconazole group.
population_specificity: Patients with acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) receiving remission-induction chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the tolerability of a curcumin mouthwash and describe its effects on oral mucositis in pediatric patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The curcumin mouthwash was found to be safe and well-tolerated, with no oral or systemic adverse events reported. In compliant patients, mucositis severity scores were lower than previously reported in literature, suggesting potential efficacy.
population_specificity: Pediatric and young-adult oncology patients undergoing high-dose chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 10 drops of Curcumall twice per day in a mouthwash.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorhexidine mouthwash with an antidiscoloration system on stain, plaque accumulation, and gingivitis compared to a placebo and chlorhexidine without the system.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine with an antidiscoloration system did not prevent plaque or gingivitis development and showed no superior effect over placebo. Significant differences in discoloration, plaque, and gingivitis were observed between the chlorhexidine groups with and without the antidiscoloration system.
population_specificity: 26 students
effective_dosage: 10 mL mouthwash or placebo, twice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of LME mouthwash on antifungal drug resistance and genotype changes in oral Candida, as well as compare its allergy profile and user satisfaction to chlorhexidine mouthwash.
results_summary: LME mouthwash did not induce antifungal drug resistance or significant genotype changes in oral Candida, and user satisfaction for taste and smell was comparable to chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: HIV-infected subjects (n=29) and denture wearers (n=38).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature and define clinical practice guidelines for the use of anti-inflammatory mouthwashes (e.g., benzydamine) in preventing and treating oral mucositis in cancer patients.
results_summary: Benzydamine mouthwash was recommended for preventing oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients receiving moderate-dose radiation therapy (up to 50 Gy) without chemotherapy. Misoprostol mouthwash was suggested against for the same purpose. Other anti-inflammatory agents showed positive results but lacked sufficient evidence for guidelines.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients receiving moderate-dose radiation therapy (up to 50 Gy) without concomitant chemotherapy.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of curcumin mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash as adjuncts to scaling and root planing in treating chronic gingivitis.
results_summary: Both curcumin and chlorhexidine mouthwashes showed statistically significant improvements in gingival and plaque indices compared to scaling and root planing alone, with no significant difference between the two mouthwashes. Curcumin was found to be comparable to chlorhexidine in anti-inflammatory and anti-microbial effects.
population_specificity: 30 patients aged 20-40 years with generalized chronic gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the day-long effectiveness of an herbal mucoadhesive tablet, placebo, and commercial mouthwash in reducing oral malodor.
results_summary: The herbal mucoadhesive tablet significantly reduced malodor scores, VSC levels, and β-galactosidase activity compared to placebo, achieving clinically meaningful odor reduction. The commercial mouthwash's performance relative to the herbal tablet or placebo was not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 40 young healthy subjects (mean age 25.8 ± 1.8 yrs, 19 females) with oral malodor.
study_duration: One evening and the following morning

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of 0.8% arginine, potassium nitrate, and sodium fluoride mouthwashes in reducing dentine hypersensitivity.
results_summary: The arginine mouthwash showed statistically significant improvements in tactile and air-blast hypersensitivity scores after two, four, and six weeks compared to potassium nitrate and negative control mouthwashes. No differences were observed after thirty minutes of a single use among the groups.
population_specificity: Subjects in the Dominican Republic (75 enrolled, 69 completed).
effective_dosage: Twice-daily use of mouthwash containing 0.8% arginine, 2.4% potassium nitrate, or 0.05% sodium fluoride (control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of three different mouthwash regimens (containing arginine, potassium, or a fluoride/arginine-free control) in reducing dentine hypersensitivity when used alongside toothpaste and toothbrushing.
results_summary: The arginine-based mouthwash regimen showed statistically significant improvements in both Tactile and Air-Blast hypersensitivity scores at all time points, outperforming the potassium-based regimen and the control. The potassium regimen showed significant improvement only in Air-Blast hypersensitivity, while the arginine regimen provided faster relief.
population_specificity: 120 subjects (118 completed) in the Dominican Republic with dentine hypersensitivity.
effective_dosage: Mouthwash containing 0.8% arginine, PVM/MA copolymer, pyrophosphates, and 0.05% sodium fluoride (Regimen 1); 0.51% potassium chloride and 230 ppm sodium fluoride (Regimen 2); fluoride/arginine-free (Regimen 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dentin hypersensitivity reduction efficacy of an arginine-containing mouthwash compared to a negative control mouthwash.
results_summary: The arginine mouthwash group showed statistically significant improvements in tactile and air blast hypersensitivity scores after two, four, and eight weeks compared to the negative control. The study concluded that the arginine mouthwash significantly reduced dentin hypersensitivity over eight weeks.
population_specificity: Subjects with two hypersensitive teeth (tactile score 10-50 g, air blast score 2 or 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of periodontal treatment, including chlorhexidine mouthwash, on reducing preterm birth risk and explore heterogeneity among studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant reduction in preterm birth with periodontal treatment overall, but daily chlorhexidine mouthwash use was associated with a reduction in preterm birth (RR: 0.69; 95% CI: 0.50 to 0.95). Heterogeneity among studies was noted, possibly due to bias, income level, or mouthwash use.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of local interventions, including chlorhexidine mouthwash and gel, for the prevention and treatment of alveolar osteitis (dry socket) following tooth extraction.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash (0.12% and 0.2%) and gel (0.2%) significantly reduced the incidence of dry socket compared to placebo, with moderate-quality evidence. Other interventions lacked sufficient evidence for evaluation.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years undergoing permanent tooth extraction, primarily third molars extracted by oral surgeons.
effective_dosage: 0.12% and 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash (rinse before and after extraction); 0.2% chlorhexidine gel (placed post-extraction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether suppressing oral nitrate-reducing bacteria with chlorhexidine-based mouthwash affects systemic nitrite levels and blood pressure in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Antiseptic mouthwash reduced oral nitrite production by 90% and plasma nitrite levels by 25%, leading to a 2-3.5 mmHg increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, which correlated with decreased nitrite concentrations. The blood pressure effect appeared within one day and persisted throughout the 7-day intervention.
population_specificity: 19 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-plaque efficacy of Triphala, Hi Ora, Chlorhexidine, and Colgate Plax mouthwashes over 24 hours.
results_summary: Triphala, Hi Ora, and Chlorhexidine significantly reduced plaque formation compared to Colgate Plax, with Triphala and Hi Ora showing efficacy similar to Chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects in a controlled, randomized, double-blind, crossover clinical trial.
study_duration: Each experimental phase was preceded by a 28-day washout period, with plaque recorded after one undisturbed day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rinsing with mouthwashes containing 500 ppm F or 225 ppm F on post-brushing salivary fluoride retention compared to not rinsing.
results_summary: Rinsing with either 500 ppm F or 225 ppm F mouthwash significantly increased fluoride levels in saliva compared to not rinsing, with the 500 ppm F rinse showing a greater effect than the 225 ppm F rinse. All comparisons were statistically significant (p < 0.01).
population_specificity: 30 volunteers
effective_dosage: 10 mL of mouthwash containing either 500 ppm F or 225 ppm F, used once after brushing with 1450 ppm F toothpaste.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a new arginine-based desensitizing mouthwash in reducing tooth sensitivity symptoms, either alone or as an adjunct to arginine-containing dentifrice.
results_summary: The study found that the arginine-based mouthwash effectively reduced sensitivity symptoms, providing relief comparable to or better than traditional potassium salt dentifrices, with potential for faster action. Clinical studies supported its efficacy as a standalone treatment or in combination with arginine dentifrice.
population_specificity: Individuals with tooth sensitivity (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most comfortable volume of mouthwash (5, 10, 15, 20, or 30 ml) for rinsing based on patient perceptions.
results_summary: The 15-ml volume was perceived as the most comfortable (mean score 5.40), while other volumes scored significantly lower (1.89 to 8.65). The differences between volumes were statistically significant, and the results showed moderate correlation between repeated assessments (0.4-0.6).
population_specificity: 62 participants in a clinical trial setting.
effective_dosage: 5, 10, 15, 20, and 30 ml volumes tested in randomized order.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted twice, 1 week apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of 0.12% chlorhexidine digluconate mouthwash in inhibiting the periodontal pathogen Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans on metallic brackets during orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash significantly reduced the presence (83% vs. 100% in controls) and levels of A. actinomycetemcomitans on brackets, demonstrating its efficacy in inhibiting this pathogen.
population_specificity: 35 patients aged 14-22 years undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine digluconate, rinsed twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chlorhexidine 0.2% mouthwash versus chlorhexidine 1% gel as adjunct treatments for peri-implant mucositis.
results_summary: Both chlorhexidine 0.2% mouthwash and 1% gel were equally effective in reducing inflammatory parameters and probing depth in peri-implant mucositis, though patients preferred the gel despite finding it harder to use.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with peri-implant mucositis (23 completed follow-ups).
study_duration: 3 months (follow-ups at 10 days, 1 month, and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cytokine and growth factor agents, including granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor mouthwash, for preventing or treating oral mucositis in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study suggested against using granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor mouthwash for preventing oral mucositis in high-dose chemotherapy followed by stem cell transplantation. No guideline was possible for other cytokine or growth factor agents due to inconclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Patients receiving high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous or allogeneic stem cell transplantation for hematological malignancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the frequency of yeast colonization in the oral cavity of hemodialysis patients with chronic renal failure and assess the antifungal susceptibility profile of the isolated yeasts.
results_summary: The study found a 39% yeast colonization rate in patients, predominantly Candida albicans, with significant colonization in those over 45 years and denture wearers. Yeasts were generally sensitive to antifungals, but non-C. albicans species required higher fluconazole concentrations.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic renal failure undergoing hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antibacterial effects of chlorhexidine gluconate and herbal mouthwashes in ICU patients.
results_summary: Both Matrica® (herbal) and chlorhexidine mouthwashes significantly reduced Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus, but chlorhexidine was more effective. The reduction in bacterial colonies was significant for both (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 60 ICU patients.
study_duration: Single use (salivary samples taken before and 6 minutes after rinsing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Aloe vera mouthwash could prevent radiation-induced mucositis and reduce oral candidiasis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study suggests that Aloe vera mouthwash may prevent radiation-induced mucositis through wound healing and anti-inflammatory mechanisms and reduce oral candidiasis due to its antifungal and immunomodulatory properties. However, no specific clinical results or statistical significance were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining an oxygenating agent (OA) with chlorhexidine digluconate (CHX) mouthwash reduces CHX-induced tooth staining without compromising plaque growth inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that combining an OA with CHX mouthwash significantly reduced tooth staining and plaque scores compared to CHX alone, with moderate evidence supporting these effects. One study reported a side effect for one participant, but overall, the combination was effective.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects aged 16 years or older.
study_duration: Intermediate length studies (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if using Listerine mouthwash before topical nasal lidocaine administration improves pain and comfort outcomes during flexible nasolaryngoscopy (FNL).
results_summary: Listerine mouthwash prior to lidocaine nasal spray significantly reduced pain and discomfort during FNL, particularly in patients undergoing extended nasal examinations. Lidocaine alone also reduced pain and discomfort compared to placebo, but the combination with Listerine showed the greatest benefit.
population_specificity: 120 patients undergoing FNL, with a subset having extended or full bilateral nasal examinations.

study_goal: To determine the effects of a 0.2% alcohol-free chlorhexidine mouthwash applied twice daily for 30 days on plaque, gingivitis, and Candida albicans in elderly denture wearers.
results_summary: The mouthwash significantly improved plaque and gingival indices and reduced Candida albicans colony-forming units compared to placebo. The study concluded that the mouthwash provided clinical benefits for antiplaque and antigingivitis effects.
population_specificity: Denture wearers over 65 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the sensitivity of digital plaque imaging in distinguishing the effectiveness of a 0.05% CPC mouthwash versus a placebo in reducing plaque on different tooth surfaces.
results_summary: The CPC mouthwash showed significant plaque reduction on lingual surfaces compared to placebo, but no significant differences were observed on facial surfaces. Digital imaging effectively distinguished between the two products, particularly on lingual surfaces.
population_specificity: 60 subjects (58 completed) who underwent scaling and polishing before the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and antiplaque efficacy of honey mouthwash compared to 0.2% chlorhexidine in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Honey mouthwash effectively inhibited six oral bacteria and reduced plaque formation, though chlorhexidine showed lower minimum inhibitory concentrations. Both honey and chlorhexidine rinses significantly reduced plaque compared to saline.
population_specificity: 66 volunteers aged 20-24 years.
effective_dosage: Concentrations tested: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256, and 512 μg/mL (in vitro); specific dosage for in vivo not detailed.
